issues.description: The solution's PersonResource implementation diverges from the API behavior described in the problem statement (and from how NoteResource is implemented). The problem asks for standard CRUD endpoints for persons where POST returns the saved person in the response body, GET /persons returns a list of persons (an empty list if none), PUT returns the updated person, and DELETE returns 204 No Content. In the solution, getAllPersons returns 404 Not Found when the list is empty (instead of returning 200 OK with an empty list), and createPerson returns unconventional status codes (returns 201 Created for an invalid input case and 202 Accepted for the success case) rather than returning a bad request on invalid input and the saved person in the response body (e.g., ResponseEntity.ok(savedPerson) or 201 Created with body). These differences are structural API/response-semantic mismatches that will confuse students implementing client code and testing behavior against the specification and will cause incorrect expectations when comparing to NoteResource.
issues.suggested_fix:
Make PersonResource conform to the described/expected semantics (and to NoteResource style):
- GET /persons should always return 200 OK with the list of persons (possibly empty). Do not return 404 when the list is empty.
- POST /persons should reject requests that include an ID with ResponseEntity.badRequest().build(); on success return the saved person in the body (e.g. ResponseEntity.ok(personService.savePerson(person)) or ResponseEntity.status(HttpStatus.CREATED).body(savedPerson)).
- Ensure PUT and DELETE follow the same semantics as NoteResource (PUT returns the updated person via ok(...), DELETE returns noContent()).
This will align the solution with the problem statement and avoid confusing students or breaking client expectations.

issues.description: The Problem Statement (Part 2, description of PersonController) incorrectly states that each PersonController method takes a Consumer<List<Note>> parameter. This conflicts with the template and solution code where the PersonController methods use Consumer<List<Person>>. The mismatch (Note vs Person) is likely a copy-paste typo and can confuse students about the expected types and signatures when implementing the client-side controller.
issues.suggested_fix: Correct the Problem Statement text to state that each PersonController method takes a Consumer<List<Person>> parameter (not Consumer<List<Note>>). This aligns the textual specification with the template and solution code and avoids type/signature confusion for students.
